description: From Middle English blessen, from Old English bletsian (“to consecrate (with blood)”), from Proto-West Germanic *blōdisōn (“to sprinkle, mark or hallow with blood”), from Proto-Germanic *blōþą (“blood”), of uncertain origin, possibly from Proto-Indo-European *bʰleh₃- (“to bloom”). Cognate with Old Norse bleza (“to bless”) (whence Icelandic blessa), Old English blēdan (“to bleed”). More at bleed.

verbs.description: bless (third-person singular simple present blesses, present participle blessing, simple past and past participle blest or blessed)

entries.meaning: To make something holy by religious rite, sanctify.
To make the sign of the cross upon, so as to sanctify.
To honor as holy, glorify; to extol for excellence.
To esteem or account happy; to felicitate.
(Perl programming, transitive, past tense only blessed) To turn (a reference) into an object.
(archaic, with from) To secure, defend, or prevent from.

description: An ellipsis for an expression such as bless your heart.
